paragraphs.text:
%md
# Matrix multiplication and cache

Welcome to the notebook with the asasignment for the third session. You’re well on your way to obtain the Wizeline Certification for Big Data Engineering with Spark!

If you have any feedback about our courses, email us at academy@wizeline.com or use the Academy Slack channel.

msg.data:
Matrix multiplication and cache

Welcome to the notebook with the asasignment for the third session. You’re well on your way to obtain the Wizeline Certification for Big Data Engineering with Spark!

If you have any feedback about our courses, email us at academy@wizeline.com or use the Academy Slack channel.

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Big Matrix Multiplication Example

In this example, you will be able to compare with different caching on a big Matrix multiplication on a larger dataset than the one you’ve used so far.

You will be challenged to work with one big Dataset, transform them into `CoordinateMatrix` object, convert it to a `BlockMatrix`, and calculate a polynomial with that matrix

msg.data:
Big Matrix Multiplication Example

In this example, you will be able to compare with different caching on a big Matrix multiplication on a larger dataset than the one you’ve used so far.

You will be challenged to work with one big Dataset, transform them into CoordinateMatrix object, convert it to a BlockMatrix, and calculate a polynomial with that matrix

paragraphs.text:
%md

The file is formatted with the following characteristics:
    - Each line in the text file is a row in the matrix. 
    - They are comma-separated values. 
    - The first value is the row index starting at one, the remaining values are the Matrix values.

msg.data:
The file is formatted with the following characteristics:
- Each line in the text file is a row in the matrix.
- They are comma-separated values.
- The first value is the row index starting at one, the remaining values are the Matrix values.

paragraphs.text:
%md

First, import the libraries to use during the session with the following command:

msg.data: First, import the libraries to use during the session with the following command:

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
from pyspark.sql.functions import array, posexplode
from pyspark.mllib.linalg.distributed import CoordinateMatrix, BlockMatrix

%md
Next, use `spark.read.csv` to read the big matrix (bigMatrix.txt) on the bucket URI: 
`gs://de-training-input/bigMatrix/bigMatrix.txt`.

And again, as you did before the function already takes into account the commas. No need to map a split by “,” while reading the files. The objects will already be DataFrames.

msg.data:
Next, use spark.read.csv to read the big matrix (bigMatrix.txt) on the bucket URI:
gs://de-training-input/bigMatrix/bigMatrix.txt.

And again, as you did before the function already takes into account the commas. No need to map a split by “,” while reading the files. The objects will already be DataFrames.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
big_matrix = spark.read.csv("gs://de-training-input/matrices/matrixbig1/*.csv.gz")

%md
Unlike the Scala version, in PySpark we’ll use Tuples and DataFrames to work with the data.

**Transform to tuples**
Now that we have loaded the data into Spark as DataFrames, we need to transform them into Tuples. The code pieces you will require to do this are:
* **.columns**: DataFrame attribute to manipulate its columns. It outputs a List of values. You can slice it similarly to a Python list.
* **array()**: Receives a List of values to convert it into an array.
* **posexplode()**: Transposes an array and adds the index position to the left. Output is two columns.
* **.select()**: DataFrame method to extract or define new columns of data.

Store the output of the final select in a variable for each Matrix.

**HINT:** `_c0` can be used to reference the first column in the object read by `spark.read.csv` if no names were provided inside the file.

msg.data:
Unlike the Scala version, in PySpark we’ll use Tuples and DataFrames to work with the data.

Transform to tuples
Now that we have loaded the data into Spark as DataFrames, we need to transform them into Tuples. The code pieces you will require to do this are:
* .columns: DataFrame attribute to manipulate its columns. It outputs a List of values. You can slice it similarly to a Python list.
* array(): Receives a List of values to convert it into an array.
* posexplode(): Transposes an array and adds the index position to the left. Output is two columns.
* .select(): DataFrame method to extract or define new columns of data.

Store the output of the final select in a variable for each Matrix.

HINT: _c0 can be used to reference the first column in the object read by spark.read.csv if no names were provided inside the file.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
big_matrix_e = big_matrix.select('_c0', posexplode(array(big_matrix.columns[1:])))

%md
Now that we have converted all of our lines into coordinate `Tuples` (Triplets), we need to put them all inside a `BlockMatrix`. The function `create_blockMatrix`, defined in another notebook receives one of the previous objects and uses a `CoordinateMatrix` to output a `BlockMatrix`.

msg.data: Now that we have converted all of our lines into coordinate Tuples (Triplets), we need to put them all inside a BlockMatrix. The function create_blockMatrix, defined in another notebook receives one of the previous objects and uses a CoordinateMatrix to output a BlockMatrix.

paragraphs.text:
%md
Now we convert the DataFrame into a `BlockMatrix`:

msg.data: Now we convert the DataFrame into a BlockMatrix:

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
block_big_M1 = create_blockMatrix(big_matrix_e)

%md
Now image you have these polynomials where `x` is our Big Matrix and we need to save the result of each operation on a file

```
3x^3 + x^2
```
and

```
x^3 + 2x^2 + x
```

msg.data:
Now image you have these polynomials where x is our Big Matrix and we need to save the result of each operation on a file

3x^3 + x^2

and

x^3 + 2x^2 + x

paragraphs.text:
%md

If we just run the operation like it is and save it, it would take a consider time to complete

msg.data: If we just run the operation like it is and save it, it would take a consider time to complete

paragraphs.text:
%md
We define our `x`

```
x = block_big_M1
```

msg.data:
We define our x

x = block_big_M1

paragraphs.text:
%md
Calculate x^2 and x^3

```
x3 = x.multiply(x).multiply(x)
x2 = x.multiply(x)
```

msg.data:
Calculate x^2 and x^3

x3 = x.multiply(x).multiply(x)
x2 = x.multiply(x)

paragraphs.text:
%md
Save the x^2 and x^3

```
x2.toCoordinateMatrix().entries.saveAsTextFile("gs://de-training-output-<user-name>/bigMatrixExample-polynomialx2.txt")
x3.toCoordinateMatrix().entries.saveAsTextFile("gs://de-training-output-<user-name>/bigMatrixExample-polynomialx3.txt")
```

msg.data:
Save the x^2 and x^3

x2.toCoordinateMatrix().entries.saveAsTextFile("gs://de-training-output-<user-name>/bigMatrixExample-polynomialx2.txt")
x3.toCoordinateMatrix().entries.saveAsTextFile("gs://de-training-output-<user-name>/bigMatrixExample-polynomialx3.txt")

paragraphs.text:
%md
Compute the result and save it

```
result1 = x3.add(x3).add(x3).add(x2)

result1.toCoordinateMatrix().entries.saveAsTextFile("gs://de-training-output-<user-name>/bigMatrixExample-polynomial1.txt")
```

msg.data:
Compute the result and save it

result1 = x3.add(x3).add(x3).add(x2)

result1.toCoordinateMatrix().entries.saveAsTextFile("gs://de-training-output-<user-name>/bigMatrixExample-polynomial1.txt")

paragraphs.text:
%md
Repeat the proccess but now for our second polynomial

```
result2a = x2.multiply(x).add(x2).add(x2).add(x)

result2a.toCoordinateMatrix().entries.saveAsTextFile("gs://de-training-output-<user-name>/bigMatrixExample-polynomial2a.txt")
```

msg.data:
Repeat the proccess but now for our second polynomial

result2a = x2.multiply(x).add(x2).add(x2).add(x)

result2a.toCoordinateMatrix().entries.saveAsTextFile("gs://de-training-output-<user-name>/bigMatrixExample-polynomial2a.txt")

paragraphs.text:
%md
Here, an other workaround to calculate the second polynomial

We calculate ` x^2 + x`
```
x3 = x.multiply(x).add(x)
```

Then `x^3 + x^2 + x^2 + x => x^3 + 2x^2 + x`
```
result2b = x3.multiply(x).add(x3)
```

And at least, we save the result
```
result2b.toCoordinateMatrix().entries.saveAsTextFile("gs://de-training-output-<user-name>/bigMatrixExample-polynomial2b.txt")
```

msg.data:
Here, an other workaround to calculate the second polynomial

We calculate x^2 + x

x3 = x.multiply(x).add(x)

Then x^3 + x^2 + x^2 + x => x^3 + 2x^2 + x

result2b = x3.multiply(x).add(x3)

And at least, we save the result

result2b.toCoordinateMatrix().entries.saveAsTextFile("gs://de-training-output-<user-name>/bigMatrixExample-polynomial2b.txt")

paragraphs.text:
%md
We are going to define a variable to be used instead of your username, **please modify it!**%md

msg.data: We are going to define a variable to be used instead of your username, please modify it!%md

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
theUsername = "rodrigochaparro"

%pyspark
x = block_big_M1
x3 = x.multiply(x).multiply(x)
x2 = x.multiply(x)
x2.toCoordinateMatrix().entries.saveAsTextFile("gs://de-training-output-{}/bigMatrixExample-polynomialx2.txt".format(theUsername))
x3.toCoordinateMatrix().entries.saveAsTextFile("gs://de-training-output-{}/bigMatrixExample-polynomialx3.txt".format(theUsername))
result1 = x3.add(x3).add(x3).add(x2)
result1.toCoordinateMatrix().entries.saveAsTextFile("gs://de-training-output{}/bigMatrixExample-polynomial1.txt".format(theUsername))
result2a = x2.multiply(x).add(x2).add(x2).add(x)
result2a.toCoordinateMatrix().entries.saveAsTextFile("gs://de-training-output-{}/bigMatrixExample-polynomial2a.txt".format(theUsername))
x3 = x.multiply(x).add(x)
result2b = x3.multiply(x).add(x3)
result2b.toCoordinateMatrix().entries.saveAsTextFile("gs://de-training-output-{}/bigMatrixExample-polynomial2b.txt".format(theUsername))

%md

Do you see how much time is needed to complete the operation?

Let's apply some cache

msg.data:
Do you see how much time is needed to complete the operation?

Let’s apply some cache

paragraphs.text:
%md
**Note:** we are converting the `BlockMatrix` back to `CoordinateMatrix` for writing purposes.

msg.data: Note: we are converting the BlockMatrix back to CoordinateMatrix for writing purposes.

paragraphs.text:
%md
Once the computation is over, save the results to your output bucket. To do so, you will need to transform the `matrix` object into a `CoordinateMatrix`. Then point to its `entries` attribute, using the `saveAsTextFile` method. Use the following GCS URI template:
Make sure to replace `<user-name>` with your personal username ID.

msg.data:
Once the computation is over, save the results to your output bucket. To do so, you will need to transform the matrix object into a CoordinateMatrix. Then point to its entries attribute, using the saveAsTextFile method. Use the following GCS URI template:
Make sure to replace <user-name> with your personal username ID.

paragraphs.text:
%md
Also, cache applied to `x2`, so it will not be computed again.

```
x2 = x.multiply(x).cache()
```

msg.data:
Also, cache applied to x2, so it will not be computed again.

x2 = x.multiply(x).cache()

paragraphs.text:
%md
And at least the cache is applied to `x3bis`

```
x3bis = x.multiply(x).add(x)
```

msg.data:
And at least the cache is applied to x3bis

x3bis = x.multiply(x).add(x)

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
x = block_big_M1
x.cache()
x2 = x.multiply(x).cache()
x3 = x2.multiply(x)
x2.toCoordinateMatrix().entries.saveAsTextFile("gs://de-training-output-{}/bigMatrixExample-polynomialx2Cache.txt".format(theUsername))
x3.toCoordinateMatrix().entries.saveAsTextFile("gs://de-training-output-{}/bigMatrixExample-polynomialx3Cache.txt".format(theUsername))
result1 = x3.add(x3).add(x3).add(x2)
result1.toCoordinateMatrix().entries.saveAsTextFile("gs://de-training-output-{}/bigMatrixExample-polynomial1Cache.txt".format(theUsername))
result2a = x2.multiply(x).add(x2).add(x2).add(x)
result2a.toCoordinateMatrix().entries.saveAsTextFile("gs://de-training-output-{}/bigMatrixExample-polynomial2aCache.txt".format(theUsername))
x3bis = x.multiply(x).add(x).cache()
result2b = x3bis.multiply(x).add(x3bis)
result2b.toCoordinateMatrix().entries.saveAsTextFile("gs://de-training-output-{}/bigMatrixExample-polynomial2bCache.txt".format(theUsername))

paragraphs.title: Exercise Time!
paragraphs.text:
%md

Calculate this polynomial,and write the result in: `"gs://de-training-output-<user-name>/bigMatrixExample-exerciseResult.txt"`

```
x^11 + x^9 + x^7 + x^5 + x^4 + x^3 + x^2 + x
```
